topics.title: Introduction
topics.summary: Statistical simulation refers to the use of random sampling techniques to model and analyze complex systems or stochastic processes. It helps approximate results that are otherwise difficult to compute analytically.

topics.title: Motivation
topics.summary: Analytical solutions to realâ€‘world problems are often infeasible due to their mathematical complexity. Statistical simulation allows us to understand uncertainty, test hypotheses, and evaluate the performance of statistical estimators.

subtopics.title: Random number generation using probability distributions
subtopics.narration: The simulation process begins with generating random numbers that follow specified probability distributions.

subtopics.title: Sampling from populations or theoretical distributions
subtopics.narration: Samples are drawn either from actual populations or from theoretical distributions to represent variability.

subtopics.title: Repeated trials to approximate expected values
subtopics.narration: By conducting many repeated trials, the simulation approximates expected values of interest.

subtopics.title: Using simulation outcomes for inference and prediction
subtopics.narration: The results of the simulated trials are then used for statistical inference and to make predictions about future observations.

topics.title: Random Number Generation Using Probability Distributions
topics.summary: An overview of techniques for generating random numbers that follow specific probability distributions, which is the foundation for any statistical simulation.
